description.summary: The eight-legged horse of Odin in Norse mythology, fastest of all horses, capable of traveling between the Nine Worlds. Born from Loki in mare form after mating with the stallion Svaðilfari.
description.full: Sleipnir is the eight-legged grey horse of Odin, the Allfather in Norse mythology. Born from the trickster god Loki (who transformed into a mare) and the jötunn's stallion Svaðilfari, Sleipnir is described as the best and fastest of all horses. With eight legs, Sleipnir can travel across land, sea, and air, and journey between the Nine Worlds of Norse cosmology, including the realm of the dead. The horse famously carried Hermóðr to Hel in an attempt to retrieve the god Baldr. Sleipnir's teeth are carved with runes, marking his magical nature. As Odin's exclusive mount, Sleipnir symbolizes shamanic journeys, the crossing of boundaries between life and death, and the ability to traverse all realms of existence. The eight-legged horse appears throughout Norse mythology and art as an emblem of supernatural travel and divine power.

origin_story.birth: Born to Loki (in mare form) after mating with the jötunn's stallion Svaðilfari during the building of Asgard's wall

parents.father: Svaðilfari (powerful stallion belonging to a jötunn/giant)

origin_story.context: The gods hired a builder to construct Asgard's wall, promising the sun, moon, and Freyja as payment if completed in impossible time. When the builder's stallion Svaðilfari made success likely, Loki transformed into a mare to distract the stallion, ultimately giving birth to Sleipnir.

major_myths.title: Birth and the Building of Asgard
major_myths.description: Created when Loki, as a mare, lured away the builder's stallion Svaðilfari, preventing completion of Asgard's wall

major_myths.title: Hermóðr's Journey to Hel
major_myths.description: After Baldr's death, Odin lent Sleipnir to Hermóðr to ride to Hel and attempt to bring Baldr back from the dead

major_myths.title: Odin's Shamanic Journeys
major_myths.description: Sleipnir carries Odin on his travels between worlds, including journeys to gain wisdom

major_myths.title: Fastest of All Horses

mythology.cultural_significance: Sleipnir embodies the Norse concept of movement between worlds and the breaking of boundaries. The eight-legged motif appears in Viking art and may represent shamanic practices. Sleipnir is a symbol of supernatural travel and divine knowledge.

cultural_range.spread: Across Norse cultural sphere, including British Isles, Iceland, Greenland during Viking Age
